case_name: Shri Ambica Mills Co. Ltd. v. Respondent No. 1

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 243 of 1959 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 24, 1958, of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 874 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 243 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 24, 1958, of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 874 of 1958.

facts.text: Appellant Shri Ambica Mills Co. Ltd. is a textile mill working at Ahmedabad.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Shri Ambica Mills Co. Ltd., is a textile mill working at Ahmedabad.

facts.text: Three employees named Punamchand, Shamaldas and Vishnuprasad made an application to the authority under s. 16 of the Payment of Wages Act for delayed wages against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Three of its employees named Punamchand, Shamaldas and Vishnuprasad made an application to the authority under s. 16 of the Act and prayed for an order against the appellant to pay them their delayed wages.

facts.text: Standardisation Award pronounced by Industrial Tribunal on April 21, 1948, in Industrial Reference No. 18 of 1947 fixed wages for different categories of workers in textile mills at Ahmedabad, including hand-folders at Rs. 36-9-0 per month.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that an award called the Standardisation Award which companyered the mill industry in Ahmedabad was pronounced by the Industrial Tribunal on April 21, 1948, in Industrial Reference No. 18 of 1947.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal directed that persons doing cut-looking as well as folding should be paid the rate earned by out-lookers in Bombay (head cut-looker Rs. 52, cut-looker Rs. 42-4-0).

anchor.surface_text: At the same time, it was observed, we desire to make it clear that if there are persons who are doing cut-looking as well as folding, they should be paid the rate earned by the out-lookers in Bombay.

facts.text: Agreement between Ahmedabad Mill Owners Association and Textile Labour Association on wages for clerks reached on June 22, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: This agreement was reached on June 22, 1949. Clauses 2 and 5 of this agreement are material for the purpose of this appeal.

facts.text: Agreement Clause 5 provides scale Rs. 40-3-70-EB-4-90-5-105 for employees like cut-looker occupying position lower than full-fledged clerk but higher than operative.

anchor.surface_text: A separate scale for those of the employees who occupy the position lower than that of a full-fledged Clerk but higher than that of an operative will be provided as under- Rs. 40-3-70-EB-4-90-5-105. This scale will be applicable in case of ... cut-looker ...

facts.text: Vishnuprasad and Punamchand applied to authority in Applications Nos. 39 and 40 of 1954 claiming delayed wages under paragraph 16 of the 1947 award.

anchor.surface_text: Vishnuprasad and Punamchand applied before the authority  Applications Nos. 39 and 40 of 1954  and claimed delayed wages against the appellant on the ground that they were entitled to higher wages under paragraph 16 of the award in Reference No. 18 of 1947.

facts.text: Authority on September 2, 1954 held Punamchand and Vishnuprasad were folders doing cut-looking entitled to Rs. 42-4-0 per month instead of Rs. 36-9-0.

anchor.surface_text: All these companytentions were rejected by the authority. ... the authority came to the companyclusion that both the applicants were folders doing cut-looking, and companysequently they were entitled each to Rs. 42-4-0 per month ... This decision was announced on September 2, 1954.

facts.text: On July 11, 1955, the present respondents moved the authority under s. 16 claiming they were semi-clerks governed by cl. 5 of the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: On July 11, 1955, the present respondents moved the authority under s. 16 of the Act. They urged that they were semi-clerks and occupied a position lower than that of a full-fledged clerk and higher than that of an operative, and as such they were governed by cl. 5 of the agreement

facts.text: Authority held against respondents on res judicata for Punamchand and Vishnuprasad, and that none were semi-clerks; dismissed applications.

anchor.surface_text: It held against the respondents and in favour of the appellant on issues 1 and 2 which related to the plea of res judicata and the status of the respondents. ... The finding of res judicata was recorded against Punamchand and Vishnuprasad.

facts.text: Appellate authority (District Judge) agreed with authority on res judicata and status, dismissed appeals.

anchor.surface_text: This decision was challenged by the respondents before the District Judge who was the appellate authority under the Act. ... the appeals preferred by the respondents were dismissed by the appellate authority on September 2, 1954.

facts.text: Bombay High Court allowed writ petition under Arts. 226 and 227, set aside orders of authorities below, remanded case to authority.

anchor.surface_text: These appellate decisions were challenged by the respondents by filing a writ petition under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution before the Bombay High Court. The Bombay High Court has held that the decision of the appellate authority was patently erroneous

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on December 12, 1960 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. December 12. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-The principal question which this appeal by special leave raises for our decision relates to the nature and extent of the jurisdiction companyferred on the authority by s. 15 of the Payment of Wages Act, 1936

facts.text: Relationship of employer and employee between appellant and the three workmen (bleach-folders: Uttarnars and Chadhavnars) is admitted.

anchor.surface_text: The relationship of employer and employee is number in dispute. It is admitted that the three workmen are employed by the appellant, and do the work of bleach-folders. These folders are classified into Uttarnars and Chadhavnars.

facts.text: Duties performed by the three respondents enumerated in joint Pursis filed before authority.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that at the trial before the authority the parties filed a joint Pursis which enumerated the duties performed by the respondents in paragraphs 2 to

facts.text: Appellant contends employees governed by Standardisation Award; respondents contend governed by cl. 5 of agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytends that the employment of the three workmen is governed by the Award which is in operation,  whereas the respondent Union companytends that they are governed by cl. 5 of the subsequent agreement.

facts.text: Authority previously found Punamchand and Vishnuprasad were doing cut-looking work.

anchor.surface_text: it came to the companyclusion that both the applicants were folders doing cut-looking

facts.text: In Ahmedabad mills, no separate class of cut-lookers as in Bombay; work done by bleach-folders.

anchor.surface_text: it is companymon ground that in Ahmedabad textile mills do number have a class of employees called cut-lookers as in Bombay. The work of cut- looking along with other kind of work is done by bleach- folders and other  folders.

facts.text: High Court held appellate authority erred in construing cls. 2 and 5 of agreement as cl. 2 determinative for cl. 5 applicability.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay High Court has held that the decision of the appellate authority was patently erroneous in law in that it proceeded on the assumption that unless cl. 2 of the agreement was satisfied cl. 5 would be inapplicable.

facts.text: Supreme Court held authority has jurisdiction under s.15 to decide if employees fall under cl.5 or Award.

anchor.surface_text: the question as to whether a particular employee is an operative falling under the Award or one who is above an operative and below the clerk falling under cl. 5 is a question which is so intimately and integrally companynected with the problem of wages

facts.text: Res judicata finding against Punamchand and Vishnuprasad held erroneous by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It also held that the finding companycurrently recorded by the authorities below on the question of res judicata against two of the respondents was manifestly erroneous.

arguments.claim: High Court exceeded its jurisdiction under Arts. 226 and 227 by interfering with the appellate authority's decision as the error was not apparent on the face of the record

anchor.surface_text: The first contention which the learned Attorney-General has raised before us on behalf of the appellant is that the High Court has exceeded its jurisdiction under Arts. 226 and 227 in interfering with the decision of the appellate authority. He contends that at the highest the error committed by the appellate authority is one of law but it is not an error apparent on the face of the record

arguments.court_reasoning: Limited but extends to incidental connected with wages; cites DCosta precedent

holdings.text: The High Court was justified in issuing a writ of certiorari to correct the error committed by the appellate authority in construing clauses 2 and 5 of the agreement, as the error was manifest and obvious, being apparent on the face of the record.

anchor.surface_text: What then is the error apparent on the face of the record which the High Court has corrected by issuing a writ of certiorari in the present case? According to the High Court the construction placed by the appellate authority on cls. 2 and 5

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl. 2 applies to clerks doing routine clerical work; cl. 5 expressly for employees not clerks nor operatives but in between, with list of designations showing irrelevance of cl. 2 test; misreading ignores plain terms and purpose of separate provisions.

holdings.text: The contention that the High Court exceeded its jurisdiction under Arts. 226 and 227 by issuing the writ is not well-founded.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the contention raised by the learned Attorney-General that by issuing the writ the High Court has exceeded its jurisdiction is not well-founded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Error in construction self-evident without elaborate argument, fitting test for error apparent on face of record as per precedents like Northumberland and Hari Vishnu Kamath.

holdings.text: The authority under s. 15 of the Payment of Wages Act has jurisdiction to decide whether a particular employee falls under the Standardisation Award as an operative or under cl. 5 of the agreement as occupying a position higher than operative but lower than full-fledged clerk, as this question is intimately connected with wages.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Question integral to determining remuneration under s. 2(vi); analogous to construing admitted contract terms; excluding it would create anomaly where employees without specific designation cannot seek speedy remedy; follows D'Costa on authority's power to determine actual contract terms.

holdings.text: Where two subsisting contracts are admitted (Award and agreement), the authority under s. 15 can decide which applies to the employee based on duties, unlike cases of rival contracts disputing subsistence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Almeda (rival contracts on subsistence) as inapplicable; applying general contract construction jurisdiction to choice between admitted subsisting contracts avoids unreasonable limitation on s.15 remedy.

holdings.text: Certiorari under Art. 226 issues to correct errors of law apparent on the face of the record, which are self-evident without elaborate argument, even if not going to jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: the extent of the Courts jurisdiction to issue a writ of certiorari under Art. 226 ... It is now well settled that the said writ can be issued not only in case of illegal exercise of jurisdiction but also to correct errors of law apparent on the face of the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restates settled law citing English (Northumberland) and Indian (Nagendra Nath Bora, Hari Vishnu Kamath) precedents; applied here but general observation.

precedents.citation: Rex v. Northumberland Compensation Appeal Tribunal The  1  1952 1 K.B. 338

anchor.surface_text: Rex v. Northumberland Compensation Appeal Tribunal The  1  1952 1 K.B. 338. writ has been supposed to be confined to the correction of excess of jurisdiction, observed Lord Justice Denning, and not to extend to the correction of errors of law and several judges have said as much.

precedents.case_name: Rex v. Northumberland Compensation Appeal Tribunal
precedents.cited_proposition: certiorari can be used to correct errors of law which appear on the face of the record even though they do not go to jurisdiction
precedents.cited_holding: the writ has been supposed to be confined to the correction of excess of jurisdiction... but... restored certiorari to its rightful position and shown that it can be used to correct errors of law which appear on the face of the record even though they do not go to jurisdiction

precedents.citation: Nagendra Nath Bora v. The Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Assam  1

anchor.surface_text: Nagendra Nath Bora v. The Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Assam  1 . It is unnecessary for us to consider in the present appeal whether or not a certiorari can issue to correct an error of fact on the ground that the impugned finding of fact is not supported by any legal evidence.

precedents.case_name: Nagendra Nath Bora v. The Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Assam
precedents.cited_proposition: errors of fact, though they may be apparent on the face of the record, cannot be corrected

precedents.cited_proposition: test for error apparent on face of record; even self-evident errors may differ by judicial opinion

precedents.cited_proposition: authority has jurisdiction to determine actual terms of contract and actual wages, but not potential wages
